How ACA Subsidies Work in 2026: Premium Tax Credits and Cost-Sharing Reductions

A breakdown of how ACA subsidies reduce health insurance costs in 2026, including how premium tax credits are calculated, what cost-sharing reductions cover, and how household income determines assistance levels.
What is the difference between premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions?

Premium tax credits lower the monthly premium paid for a marketplace plan and are available across all metal tiers. Cost-sharing reductions lower out-of-pocket costs like deductibles, copays, and coinsurance but apply only to Silver-tier plans. Both are based on household income relative to the federal poverty level.
Do ACA subsidies need to be repaid?

Premium tax credits taken in advance are reconciled when a federal tax return is filed. If actual household income for the year was higher than the estimate provided during enrollment, some or all of the advance credit may need to be repaid. If income was lower than estimated, an additional credit may be received as a tax refund.
Can someone receiving employer coverage still get marketplace subsidies?

Marketplace subsidies are generally unavailable to individuals who have access to employer-sponsored coverage that meets ACA affordability and minimum value standards. If employer coverage is deemed unaffordable -- meaning the employee's share of the premium exceeds a set percentage of household income -- marketplace subsidies may become available.

## What Are ACA Subsidies?

ACA subsidies are financial assistance programs established by the Affordable Care Act to make marketplace health insurance more affordable. Two primary forms exist: premium tax credits, which reduce monthly premiums, and cost-sharing reductions, which lower out-of-pocket expenses such as deductibles and copays.

## How Premium Tax Credits Are Calculated

Premium tax credits are calculated based on household income as a percentage of the federal poverty level (FPL). The subsidy ensures that the cost of a benchmark Silver plan does not exceed a set percentage of income. Households with lower incomes pay a smaller share, while those with higher incomes receive proportionally less assistance. The credit can be applied in advance to reduce monthly premium payments or claimed in full when filing a federal tax return.

## Understanding Cost-Sharing Reductions

Cost-sharing reductions are available exclusively on Silver-tier marketplace plans. These reductions lower the plan's deductible, copayments, and maximum out-of-pocket limits, effectively increasing the plan's actuarial value. Eligibility is generally tied to household incomes between 100% and 250% of the FPL. Unlike premium tax credits, cost-sharing reductions do not require reconciliation at tax time.

## What to Watch for in 2026

Subsidy availability in 2026 depends on current federal legislation. Enhanced premium tax credits, which removed the income cap and reduced the maximum percentage of income spent on benchmark premiums, were introduced as temporary measures. Whether these enhancements remain active for the 2026 plan year directly affects how much financial assistance is available. Checking updated subsidy calculators during open enrollment provides the most accurate estimate of expected costs.

Individual & Family Health Insurance: A Guide to ACA Marketplace Options
Learn how individual and family health insurance works through the ACA marketplace, including plan types, metal tiers, and how to choose coverage that fits your household's needs.
What is the difference between individual health insurance and employer-sponsored coverage?

Individual health insurance is purchased directly through the ACA marketplace or a private insurer, while employer-sponsored coverage is offered and partially funded by an employer. Both must meet ACA minimum essential coverage standards, but individual plans may be eligible for premium tax credits based on household income.
Can a family mix and match different marketplace plans?

Yes, members of the same household can enroll in different marketplace plans. Each family member can select a plan that best fits their provider preferences and expected medical needs, though premium tax credits are calculated for the household as a whole.
Are all ACA marketplace plans required to cover pre-existing conditions?
Yes. Under the Affordable Care Act, all marketplace plans must accept applicants regardless of pre-existing conditions and cannot charge higher premiums based on health status.

## What Is Individual & Family Health Insurance?

Individual and family health insurance is coverage purchased by a person or household rather than obtained through an employer or government program. These plans are available year-round through qualifying life events or during the annual open enrollment period via the ACA marketplace, also known as the Health Insurance Exchange.

## How the ACA Marketplace Works

The ACA marketplace is a federally facilitated or state-run exchange where consumers can compare and purchase health insurance plans. All plans sold on the marketplace are required to cover ten essential health benefits, including hospitalization, prescription drugs, maternity care, and preventive services. Plans are organized into four metal tiers -- Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum -- each representing a different balance between monthly premiums and out-of-pocket costs.

## Understanding Metal Tiers

Metal tiers indicate how costs are shared between the insurer and the covered individual. Bronze plans carry the lowest monthly premiums but the highest out-of-pocket costs when care is needed. Platinum plans have the highest premiums but cover a greater share of medical expenses. Silver plans hold a unique position because they are the only tier eligible for cost-sharing reductions, which lower deductibles and copays for qualifying households.

## Who Should Consider Marketplace Coverage?

Marketplace plans serve individuals and families who do not have access to affordable employer-sponsored insurance or government programs like Medicaid. Self-employed workers, early retirees, part-time employees, and anyone experiencing a gap in employer coverage are among those who commonly turn to the marketplace. Financial assistance in the form of premium tax credits is available to households with income between 100% and 400% of the federal poverty level, and in some years, expanded eligibility removes that upper cap entirely.

Open Enrollment 2026: Dates, Process, and What to Expect
A guide to the 2026 open enrollment period for ACA marketplace health insurance, including key dates, how to enroll, and what changes to anticipate for the upcoming plan year.
What happens if the open enrollment deadline is missed?

Missing the open enrollment deadline means marketplace coverage cannot be obtained until the next enrollment period unless a qualifying life event triggers a special enrollment period. Examples of qualifying events include losing other health coverage, getting married, having a baby, or moving to a new state.
Do existing marketplace enrollees need to re-enroll every year?

Existing enrollees are typically auto-renewed into their current plan or a similar plan if theirs is discontinued. However, reviewing and actively updating a plan selection each year is strongly recommended, as premiums, provider networks, and formularies can change significantly from year to year.

## When Does Open Enrollment for 2026 Start?

The open enrollment period for 2026 ACA marketplace coverage is expected to begin on November 1, 2025, and run through January 15, 2026, on the federal exchange at HealthCare.gov. Some state-based marketplaces set their own deadlines, which may extend later into January or beyond. Enrolling by December 15 typically ensures coverage begins on January 1 of the new plan year.

## How the Enrollment Process Works

Enrollment begins with an application on the marketplace, which collects household size, income, and current coverage information. The application determines eligibility for premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions. From there, applicants can compare available plans by premium, deductible, provider network, and drug formulary before making a selection.

## What Changes to Expect in 2026

Plan availability, premiums, and subsidy amounts shift each year based on insurer participation and federal policy. For 2026, close attention should be paid to whether enhanced premium tax credits -- originally expanded under the American Rescue Plan and extended through subsequent legislation -- remain in effect. Changes to subsidy structure can significantly alter net premium costs, making it essential to re-shop rather than rely on auto-renewal.

## Steps to Prepare Before Enrollment Opens

Preparation improves outcomes during open enrollment. Gathering documents such as projected annual income, tax filing status, and a list of current medications and preferred providers helps streamline the comparison process. Reviewing the prior year's plan performance -- including unexpected out-of-pocket costs or network limitations -- offers practical insight into what to prioritize in a new plan selection.

Special Enrollment Period: Qualifying Life Events and How to Enroll Outside Open Enrollment

Understand how special enrollment periods work, which qualifying life events trigger eligibility, and the steps required to enroll in ACA marketplace coverage outside the standard open enrollment window.
How long does a special enrollment period last?

Most special enrollment periods last 60 days from the date of the qualifying life event. Some events, such as losing Medicaid coverage, may carry different timelines. Acting promptly is important because coverage cannot be backdated, and delays may result in gaps.
Can a change in income trigger a special enrollment period?

A change in income alone does not typically trigger a special enrollment period. However, if a drop in income results in gaining or losing eligibility for Medicaid or marketplace subsidies, that change in eligibility status may open an enrollment window.
Is documentation required to verify a qualifying life event?

Yes, the marketplace may request documentation to verify the qualifying life event. Examples include a termination letter from an employer for job-based coverage loss, a marriage certificate, a birth certificate, or proof of a new address. Submitting documents promptly helps avoid delays in coverage activation.

## What Is a Special Enrollment Period?

A special enrollment period (SEP) is a window outside the standard open enrollment period during which individuals and families can sign up for or change ACA marketplace health insurance. Access to an SEP is triggered by specific qualifying life events that alter a household's coverage needs or circumstances.

## Common Qualifying Life Events

Qualifying life events fall into several broad categories. Loss of existing health coverage -- whether through job loss, aging off a parent's plan, or losing Medicaid eligibility -- is among the most common triggers. Major life changes such as marriage, divorce, the birth or adoption of a child, and a permanent move to a new zip code or county also establish eligibility. Each event type has its own documentation requirements and enrollment timeline.

## How to Enroll During a Special Enrollment Period

Enrollment during an SEP follows the same general process as open enrollment. An application is submitted through the marketplace, qualifying event details are reported, and the marketplace verifies eligibility. Once verified, available plans can be compared and selected. Coverage start dates depend on when the plan is selected relative to the qualifying event and the time of month.

## Important Timing Considerations

Deadlines are strict during a special enrollment period. Most SEPs allow 60 days from the qualifying event to complete enrollment. Reporting the event to the marketplace as early as possible preserves the full window for plan comparison and selection. Coverage effective dates vary -- enrolling between the 1st and 15th of a month typically triggers coverage on the 1st of the following month, while enrolling after the 15th may push the start date to the 1st of the month after that.

What Affects Health Insurance Costs: Age, Location, Tobacco Use, Plan Level, and Income
An overview of the primary factors that influence health insurance premiums and out-of-pocket costs, including age, geographic location, tobacco use, metal tier selection, and household income.
Why do health insurance premiums vary so much by location?

Premiums vary by location because the cost of medical care, the number of insurers competing in a region, and state regulatory requirements differ across geographic areas. Urban areas with more hospital systems may see different pricing than rural areas with fewer providers, and each state's insurance market conditions influence plan availability and cost.
Does health status affect ACA marketplace premiums?

No. Under the Affordable Care Act, insurers cannot charge higher premiums based on health status or pre-existing conditions. The only individual-level factors that can affect ACA premiums are age, location, tobacco use, and plan tier selection.
How does choosing a higher metal tier affect total healthcare spending?

Higher metal tiers such as Gold and Platinum carry higher monthly premiums but cover a larger share of medical costs when care is received. For individuals or families who expect frequent medical visits, prescriptions, or planned procedures, a higher-tier plan may reduce total annual spending despite the increased premium.

## What Determines Health Insurance Premiums?

Health insurance premiums on the ACA marketplace are determined by five primary factors: age, geographic location, tobacco use, plan metal tier, and household income (through subsidies). Unlike pre-ACA markets, current regulations prohibit insurers from adjusting premiums based on health status or gender.

## How Age Influences Cost

Age is the most significant individual rating factor for ACA premiums. Older adults are charged higher premiums than younger adults, with federal rules allowing insurers to charge up to three times more for the oldest age band compared to the youngest. This age-based pricing reflects the statistical increase in healthcare utilization as people age.

## The Role of Geographic Location

Geographic rating areas drive meaningful premium differences even within the same state. Areas with higher healthcare delivery costs, fewer competing insurers, or greater utilization patterns typically have higher premiums. A plan that costs one amount in a metropolitan area may carry a substantially different price in a rural county within the same state.

## Tobacco Use Surcharges

Insurers are permitted to apply a tobacco surcharge of up to 50% on premiums for individuals who use tobacco products. Importantly, premium tax credits do not offset the surcharge portion of the premium, meaning the additional cost falls entirely on the enrollee.

## Plan Metal Tier and Out-of-Pocket Balance

Selecting a metal tier is a direct trade-off between monthly premiums and cost-sharing at the point of care. Bronze plans offer the lowest premiums but require the enrollee to pay a larger share of costs through deductibles and copays. Platinum plans minimize out-of-pocket expenses but carry the highest monthly premiums. Evaluating expected healthcare needs for the year helps determine which tier offers the best overall value.

Health Insurance in Alabama: ACA Marketplace Guide
Learn about ACA health insurance options, subsidies, and enrollment in Alabama. Educational guide from licensed agents.
When is the ACA Open Enrollment period in Alabama?

Open Enrollment in Alabama typically runs from November 1 through January 15 each year. During this window, residents can enroll in or change their ACA Marketplace health insurance plan through Healthcare.gov.
What is the income limit for ACA subsidies in Alabama?

Premium tax credits are available to Alabama residents with household incomes between 100% and 400% of the federal poverty level. Enhanced subsidies under recent legislation have expanded eligibility further, making more households eligible for financial assistance.

## Health Insurance Options in Alabama

Alabama residents access ACA Marketplace coverage through the federal exchange at Healthcare.gov. The state has not expanded Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, which means a broader portion of the population relies on Marketplace plans for individual and family coverage. Insurers offering plans in Alabama vary by county, so available options depend on where a person lives. Plans are categorized into metal tiers -- Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum -- each representing a different balance between monthly premiums and out-of-pocket costs.

## How to Enroll in an Alabama Marketplace Plan

Enrollment takes place through Healthcare.gov during the annual Open Enrollment period. The process begins with creating an account, completing an application with household and income details, and comparing available plans. Special Enrollment Periods are available outside of Open Enrollment for those who experience qualifying life events such as losing other coverage, getting married, or having a child. Navigators and licensed agents throughout Alabama can assist with the application process at no additional cost.

## Subsidies and Financial Help in Alabama

Financial assistance through the ACA can significantly reduce the cost of health insurance for Alabama residents. Premium tax credits lower the monthly cost of a Marketplace plan, and the amount is based on household income and the cost of the benchmark Silver plan in a given area. Cost-sharing reductions, available with Silver-tier plans, reduce deductibles, copays, and maximum out-of-pocket expenses for those with eligible income levels. Because Alabama has not expanded Medicaid, understanding subsidy eligibility is especially important for lower-income residents seeking affordable coverage.

Health Insurance in California: ACA Marketplace Guide
Learn about ACA health insurance options, subsidies, and enrollment in California. Educational guide from licensed agents.

Covered California is the state-based health insurance exchange where California residents can shop for, compare, and enroll in ACA-compliant health plans. It is the only place in California where residents can access federal premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions.
Does California offer additional state subsidies for health insurance?

Yes, California provides state-funded subsidies that supplement federal premium tax credits. These additional subsidies help reduce premiums for middle-income residents who may not receive sufficient assistance through federal programs alone.

## Health Insurance Options in California

California operates its own state-based exchange, Covered California, which serves as the primary marketplace for individual and family health insurance. The state has fully expanded Medicaid (known as Medi-Cal in California), providing coverage to a broad low-income population. Covered California offers plans from multiple insurers across the state's 19 rating regions, giving residents a competitive selection of options. Plans follow the standard ACA metal tiers, and the exchange also offers enhanced plan options in some areas.

## How to Enroll in a Covered California Plan

Enrollment is handled directly through the Covered California website or by working with a certified insurance agent or enrollment counselor. The annual Open Enrollment period follows a schedule that may differ slightly from the federal marketplace timeline. Residents who experience qualifying life events can apply during a Special Enrollment Period. The Covered California application collects household size, income, and other details to determine eligibility for Medi-Cal or subsidized Marketplace coverage. In-person assistance is available at locations throughout the state.

## Subsidies and Financial Help in California

California residents may receive both federal and state-level financial assistance for health coverage. Federal premium tax credits are calculated based on income relative to the federal poverty level and the cost of the benchmark Silver plan in each region. California also funds its own subsidy program, which extends premium assistance to households with incomes above the federal threshold. Cost-sharing reductions on Silver plans further lower out-of-pocket expenses for eligible enrollees. These layered programs make California one of the most accessible states for affordable ACA coverage.

How many health insurance companies offer ACA plans in Georgia?

The number of insurers varies by county, but Georgia has seen growing participation from carriers on the Marketplace in recent years. Urban areas like metro Atlanta typically have more plan options than rural counties.
Can Georgia residents get financial help with ACA health insurance premiums?

Yes, premium tax credits are available to Georgia residents whose household income falls within the eligible range based on the federal poverty level. These credits are applied directly to monthly premiums to reduce costs.

## Health Insurance Options in Georgia

Georgia residents enroll in ACA Marketplace plans through Healthcare.gov, the federal exchange. The state has not expanded Medicaid, which affects coverage options for some lower-income residents. Georgia's Marketplace offers plans across all metal tiers, with availability varying by region. The metro Atlanta area generally has the widest selection of insurers and plans, while rural areas may have fewer choices. Understanding the differences between metal tiers helps consumers select the plan that best fits their health care needs and budget.

## How to Enroll in a Georgia Marketplace Plan

Enrollment in Georgia occurs through Healthcare.gov during the annual Open Enrollment period, which typically runs from November 1 through January 15. Creating an account, providing household and income information, and reviewing available plans are the key steps. Residents who miss Open Enrollment may still apply during a Special Enrollment Period if they experience a qualifying life event. Licensed insurance agents and certified application counselors across Georgia provide free assistance with the enrollment process and plan selection.

## Subsidies and Financial Help in Georgia

Premium tax credits can make ACA health coverage substantially more affordable for Georgia residents. The credit amount depends on household income and the local cost of the benchmark Silver plan. Cost-sharing reductions are also available for Silver plan enrollees within certain income brackets, reducing deductibles and copayments. Because Georgia has not expanded Medicaid, residents in the lower-income range should carefully evaluate their subsidy eligibility to find the most cost-effective coverage option through the Marketplace.

Health Insurance in Iowa: ACA Marketplace Guide
Learn about ACA health insurance options, subsidies, and enrollment in Iowa. Educational guide from licensed agents.
Has Iowa expanded Medicaid under the ACA?

Iowa has expanded coverage for low-income adults through a modified Medicaid expansion program. This program, known as the Iowa Health and Wellness Plan, provides coverage to adults with incomes up to 138% of the federal poverty level.
When can Iowa residents enroll in an ACA Marketplace plan?

Iowa residents can enroll through Healthcare.gov during the annual Open Enrollment period, which typically runs from November 1 through January 15. Special Enrollment Periods are available for those with qualifying life changes.

## Health Insurance Options in Iowa

Iowa residents access ACA Marketplace plans through the federal exchange at Healthcare.gov. The state provides expanded Medicaid coverage through the Iowa Health and Wellness Plan, which serves low-income adults. For those who do not qualify for Medicaid, the Marketplace offers individual and family plans across the standard metal tiers. Insurer participation in Iowa's Marketplace varies by rating area, with some rural regions having fewer carrier options than urban centers like Des Moines and Cedar Rapids.

## How to Enroll in an Iowa Marketplace Plan

Enrollment in an ACA plan in Iowa takes place at Healthcare.gov during Open Enrollment. The application process requires information about household composition, income, and current coverage status. Based on this information, the system determines eligibility for Medicaid, the Iowa Health and Wellness Plan, or subsidized Marketplace coverage. Special Enrollment Periods allow enrollment outside the standard window for those experiencing qualifying life events such as job loss, marriage, or the birth of a child. Community organizations and licensed agents throughout Iowa offer free enrollment assistance.

The state has not expanded Medicaid, which means a larger portion of the population depends on the Marketplace for individual health coverage. Multiple insurers participate in South Carolina’s exchange, with plan availability varying by county and rating area. Plans are organized into the standard metal tiers, and all must cover the ACA’s essential health benefits. Residents in both urban areas like Charleston and Columbia and more rural regions can compare options through the federal platform.

How to Enroll in a South Carolina Marketplace Plan

Enrollment occurs at Healthcare.gov during the annual Open Enrollment period, typically from November 1 through January 15. The application requires household composition and income information to assess eligibility for Medicaid, CHIP, or Marketplace premium tax credits. After completing the application, residents can browse and compare plans based on premium, deductible, network, and estimated total annual costs. Special Enrollment Periods are available for qualifying life events. Licensed insurance agents and navigator organizations across South Carolina provide free assistance with enrollment.

Subsidies and Financial Help in South Carolina

Premium tax credits are the primary form of financial assistance for South Carolina residents purchasing Marketplace coverage. The credit amount depends on household income and the cost of the benchmark Silver plan in the local area. Cost-sharing reductions for Silver plan enrollees with qualifying incomes further reduce deductibles, copays, and out-of-pocket maximums. Without Medicaid expansion, these subsidies are especially critical for making coverage accessible. Reviewing estimated costs with and without subsidies during the enrollment process helps ensure the most informed plan selection.

Has Tennessee expanded Medicaid under the ACA?

Tennessee has not expanded Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. The state's Medicaid program, TennCare, covers certain categories of low-income residents, but eligibility does not extend to all adults below 138% of the federal poverty level.
How do Tennessee residents find out which insurers offer plans in their area?

Residents can visit Healthcare.gov during Open Enrollment to see which insurers and plans are available in their county. Plan options are displayed after entering a ZIP code and basic household information, making it straightforward to compare local offerings.

## Health Insurance Options in Tennessee

Tennessee residents shop for ACA Marketplace health coverage through Healthcare.gov. The state has not expanded Medicaid, so TennCare eligibility remains limited to traditional categories. For individuals and families who do not have access to employer-sponsored coverage or Medicaid, the Marketplace offers plans across the standard metal tiers. Insurer participation in Tennessee's Marketplace has fluctuated over the years, but recent trends show increased carrier involvement, particularly in the state's larger metro areas like Nashville, Memphis, and Knoxville.

Enrollment takes place at Healthcare.gov during the annual Open Enrollment period, typically running from November 1 through January 15. Plan comparison tools allow residents to evaluate premiums, deductibles, provider networks, and covered medications side by side. Texas residents access ACA Marketplace coverage through Healthcare.gov. As the second-most-populous state, Texas has one of the largest Marketplace enrollee populations in the country. Health Insurance in Utah: ACA Marketplace Guide
Learn about ACA health insurance options, subsidies, and enrollment in Utah. Educational guide from licensed agents.
Has Utah expanded Medicaid under the ACA?

Yes, Utah voters approved Medicaid expansion through a ballot initiative in 2018, and full expansion took effect in 2020. The program covers adults with household incomes up to 138% of the federal poverty level through the state Medicaid program.
What resources are available to help Utah residents enroll in Marketplace coverage?

Utah residents can access free help from certified application counselors, community health centers, and licensed insurance agents. The Take Care Utah program and other navigator organizations provide in-person and virtual enrollment assistance statewide.

## Health Insurance Options in Utah

Utah residents enroll in ACA Marketplace plans through Healthcare.gov. The state implemented full Medicaid expansion in 2020 following voter approval, extending coverage to low-income adults. For those above the Medicaid income limit, the Marketplace offers individual and family plans in all metal tiers. Utah's exchange includes several participating insurers, with plan options varying by county. The Wasatch Front region, including Salt Lake City and Provo, typically offers the greatest selection, while more rural parts of the state may have fewer carriers.

## How to Enroll in a Utah Marketplace Plan

Enrollment for Utah residents takes place at Healthcare.gov during the annual Open Enrollment period, generally from November 1 through January 15. The application determines eligibility for Medicaid, CHIP, or subsidized Marketplace plans based on household and income information. After eligibility is established, residents can compare available plans by cost, coverage level, and provider network. Special Enrollment Periods allow enrollment outside the standard window for those with qualifying life events. Licensed insurance agents and enrollment assistance programs such as Take Care Utah offer free support throughout the process.

## Subsidies and Financial Help in Utah

Federal premium tax credits reduce monthly premiums for Utah residents who purchase Marketplace coverage, with amounts based on household income and the local benchmark Silver plan cost. Cost-sharing reductions on Silver-tier plans lower deductibles and copays for those within eligible income ranges. Utah's Medicaid expansion provides an additional avenue for low-cost comprehensive coverage. Residents near the boundary between Medicaid and Marketplace eligibility should evaluate both options, as income fluctuations during the year can affect which program provides the best value.

Estimate how your household income affects ACA marketplace subsidies. Educational calculator for understanding premium tax credits.
How does income affect health insurance subsidies?
ACA premium tax credits are based on your household income relative to the Federal Poverty Level. Lower incomes generally result in larger subsidies that reduce monthly premium costs.
Is this calculator a guarantee of savings?
No. This is an educational estimate only. Actual subsidy amounts depend on your specific circumstances, available plans in your area, and current federal guidelines.

## What This Calculator Does

This calculator provides an educational estimate of how household income may affect ACA marketplace premium tax credits. By entering basic income and household information, the tool generates an approximate view of potential monthly savings on health insurance premiums.

The Affordable Care Act ties premium tax credit amounts to household income as a percentage of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). Households earning between 100% and 400% of the FPL -- and in many cases above that threshold under extended subsidy rules -- may receive credits that lower monthly premium costs. This calculator models those relationships so users can better understand how income changes might influence financial assistance.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Start by entering total expected household income for the coverage year and the number of people in the household. The calculator then estimates where that income falls relative to the Federal Poverty Level and displays an approximate premium tax credit amount.

Results include an estimated monthly subsidy, an approximate percentage of income expected to go toward a benchmark plan premium, and a comparison showing costs with and without the estimated credit.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool is for informational and educational purposes only. It does not constitute financial, tax, or insurance advice. Actual premium tax credit amounts are determined by the Health Insurance Marketplace based on verified income, household size, age, location, and available plans. Consult a licensed insurance professional or visit HealthCare.gov for official eligibility determinations.

Is My Job's Health Plan Affordable?
Check whether your employer health plan meets ACA affordability standards. Educational tool for understanding the employer coverage threshold.
What is the ACA affordability threshold?
For 2026, employer coverage is generally considered affordable if the employee-only premium does not exceed approximately 9.02% of household income.
What happens if my employer plan is not affordable?
If employer coverage is considered unaffordable under ACA guidelines, household members may be eligible to explore marketplace coverage with potential premium tax credits.

## What This Tool Does

This tool helps determine whether an employer-sponsored health plan meets the ACA affordability standard. The ACA defines employer coverage as affordable when the employee-only premium for the lowest-cost plan does not exceed a set percentage of household income -- approximately 9.02% for 2026.

Understanding this threshold matters because access to affordable employer coverage generally affects eligibility for marketplace premium tax credits. If employer-sponsored insurance is considered affordable under ACA rules, household members covered by that offer typically cannot receive marketplace subsidies. Conversely, if the employer plan exceeds the affordability threshold, marketplace options with financial assistance may become available.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Enter the monthly employee-only premium cost for the employer plan and the household's estimated annual income. The tool then calculates the premium as a percentage of income and compares it against the current affordability threshold.

Results display whether the employer plan falls above or below the ACA affordability standard, the exact percentage of income the premium represents, and general information about what that determination may mean for marketplace eligibility.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool provides general educational information only and does not constitute legal, tax, or benefits advice. Affordability determinations involve multiple factors, including specific employer offer details and household circumstances. For a binding eligibility determination, consult the Health Insurance Marketplace or a licensed benefits advisor.

Understand the differences between ACA metal tier plans. Educational comparison of Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum health insurance levels.
What is the difference between Bronze, Silver, and Gold plans?

The metal tiers differ in how costs are shared. Bronze plans have lower premiums but higher out-of-pocket costs. Gold plans have higher premiums but lower costs when you use care. Silver plans fall in between.
There is no single best plan level. The right choice depends on your healthcare needs, budget, and whether you qualify for cost-sharing reductions, which only apply to Silver plans.

## What This Tool Does

This tool provides an educational comparison of ACA metal tier plan levels. The Affordable Care Act organizes marketplace health insurance into four metal tiers -- Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum -- each representing a different balance between monthly premiums and out-of-pocket costs when receiving care.

Bronze plans cover approximately 60% of average healthcare costs, leaving 40% to the enrollee. Silver plans cover about 70%, Gold about 80%, and Platinum about 90%. A key distinction is that cost-sharing reductions (CSRs) are available only with Silver plans for eligible lower-income households, which can significantly reduce deductibles and copays beyond what the standard Silver tier offers.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Review the side-by-side breakdown of each metal tier to compare typical premium ranges, deductible levels, copay structures, and out-of-pocket maximums. The tool highlights the trade-offs between paying more each month in premiums versus paying more at the point of care.

Results also explain how cost-sharing reductions interact specifically with Silver plans and why that feature can make Silver the most cost-effective option for many households.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool is for informational and educational purposes only. Actual plan costs, benefits, and availability vary by location, insurer, and enrollment period. The figures presented are general illustrations of how metal tiers work, not quotes for specific plans. Contact the Health Insurance Marketplace or a licensed insurance agent for plan-specific details.

What Income Counts for Health Insurance?
Understand how Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) is calculated for ACA health insurance purposes. Educational guide to income counting.
What is MAGI for health insurance?
Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) is the income figure used to determine eligibility for ACA premium tax credits. It starts with your Adjusted Gross Income and adds back certain deductions.
Does this tool replace tax advice?
No. This tool provides general educational information about how income is typically counted for ACA purposes. Consult a tax professional for advice about your specific situation.

## What This Tool Does

This tool explains which types of income are counted when determining eligibility for ACA health insurance subsidies. The ACA uses Modified Adjusted Gross Income (MAGI) as its primary income measure, and understanding what MAGI includes is an important step in estimating potential financial assistance.

MAGI starts with Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) from a federal tax return and adds back three specific items: non-taxable Social Security benefits, tax-exempt interest income, and foreign earned income that was excluded from AGI. Common income sources included in AGI -- and therefore in MAGI -- are wages, salary, self-employment income, retirement distributions, investment income, and alimony received under pre-2019 agreements.

## How to Use It and What It Shows

Select or review each income category to see whether it typically counts toward MAGI. The tool walks through common income types, identifies which ones are included, and provides brief explanations for each category.

Results offer a clearer picture of which income sources generally factor into ACA subsidy calculations and which are typically excluded, such as gifts, veterans' disability payments, and child support received.

### Educational Disclaimer

This tool is for educational purposes only and does not provide tax or financial advice. Income counting rules can vary based on individual circumstances and changes in federal regulation. For guidance specific to a particular tax situation, consult a qualified tax professional or visit IRS.gov.
